data: PED ED Mitochondrial Encephalomyopathy/Lactic Acidosis/Stroke Like Episodes (MELAS)

Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis and stroke like episodes (MELAS) presents with stroke like episodes not conformed to vascular territories. In addition to seizures, recurrent headaches, cortical vision loss, muscle weakness, recurrent vomiting, short stature, altered consciousness, hearing impairment, diabetes mellitus type 1 and 2, developmental delay and fever.     If patients present in ER with following symptoms, they require immediate attention and start of IV L-arginine infusion (in consultation with Biochemical Genetics and Neurology):   - Cliinical neurological deficit (e.g hemiparesis, focal weakness, visual loss, ataxia, dysarthria, facial palsy) with evidence of acute ischemia (restricted diffusion) on urgent brain MRI    - Intractable seizures   - Severe uncontrolled headaches    - Altered mental status    In addition, provide adequate hydration and symptom management, optimization of caloric intake to avoid catabolism and worsening of lactic acidosis.     Avoid high glucose content infusion (D10WNS), which may worsen the lactic acidosis
Immediate treatment for symptoms of stroke-like episodes may reduce the severity of the metabolic stroke.The Golden Hour is important in metabolic stroke too
Patient may have formula provided by caregiver as per patient care letter orally or via enteral tubes
For use at BCH ED only
